presentation.title: Sediment regulation: Avoided reservoir sedimentation
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from sediment regulation by ecosystems to prevent reservoir sedimentation
presentation.description: Values resulting from erosion prevention and natural sediment deposition by ecosystems, and accounting for the prevention of detrimental sedimentation of reservoirs. Flow models are used to attribute beneficial or detrimental sources of sediment or "sinks" that promote sediment deposition in relation to their human beneficiaries.

page.name: Assessment of reservoirs susceptible to sediment deposition
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This model considers hydroelectric reservoirs as a potential beneficiary of sediment regulation. Sedimentation reduces reservoir and hydroelectric generation capacity, and dredging to remove accumulated sediment and restore storage capacity can be extremely expensive. These models map flows from sediment sources (areas of erosion), sinks (areas where deposition occurs), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of sediment.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Hydrologic soils group
page.title: Hydrologic soils group
page.description:
Different soil types have different infiltration capacities. See Computing composite CN and runoff coefficients.

Role in models

Soils are classified from group A (highest infiltraiton capacity) to D (lowest infiltration capacity); group accounts for maximum yearly wetness, degree of soil freezing, bare soil surface, and swelling of clays, but does not account for slope. HSG is used along with slope, slope stability, and soil texture data to estimate soil erodibility in probabilistic erosion models. Greater erodibility is assumed in soils with higher infiltration capacity.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Sources

SSURGO soils data (U.S.); University of Vermont Spatial Analysis Lab, derived from FAO soils data (global).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: USDA-NRCS SSURGO soils database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Slope
page.title: Slope
page.description:
Slope strongly affects potential erosion by influencing slope stability and runoff speed.

Role in models

Since hydrologic soils group classifications do not account for slope, slope is used along with hydrologic soils group, slope stability, and soil texture data to estimate soil erodibility in probabilistic erosion models. Greater erodibility is assumed on steep slopes where runoff occurs quickly.

Representation

Data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Derived from a global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Derived from Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Slope stability
page.title: Slope stability
page.description:
A classification of the mechanical stability of slopes.

Role in models

Slope stability data, where available, can be used to probabilistically estimate soil erodibility. Unstable slopes are particularly prone to erosion.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

Washington State Department of Natural Resources.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Washington State DNR.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil texture
page.title: Soil texture
page.description:
Soil texture can influence its erodibility.

Role in models

Soil texture data can be used to probabilistically estimate soil erodibility. Greater erodibility is assumed for finer-textued soils.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

SSURGO soils data (U.S.); FAO soils data (global).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: USDA-NRCS SSURGO soils database, FAO Global Soils database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil erodibility
page.title: Soil erodibility
page.description:
Soil erodibility coefficients used in the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation.

Role in models

Soil erodibility estimates can either be directly used to estimate erosion using RUSLE or can be used to train Bayesian networks in probabilistic erosion models for cases where RUSLE's use is inappropriate.

Representation

Data are unitless estimates of erodibility used in the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation.

Source

USGS Effects of Energy Development in the Rocky Mountain Area (EERMA) Project (Colorado-New Mexico); SSURGO soils database (U.S.); Yang, D., et al. 2003. Global potential soil erosion with reference to land use and climate changes. Hydrological Processes 17: 2913-2928 (global).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: USGS EERMA Project, USDA-NRCS SSURGO soils database, Yang et al. (2003).
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual precipitation
page.title: Annual precipitation
page.description:
Annual precipitation.

Role in models

Precipitation data are used along with soil erodiblity and vegetative maturity to estimate overall erosion in the ad hoc erosion source models. In regions susceptible to tropical storms and with steep slopes, tropical storm probability is added as an additional influence on runoff, since these extreme storm events can cause larger event-based episodes of erosion.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation per year.

Source

PRISM Climate Group, Oregon State University (U.S.); WorldClim (global).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: WorldClim, PRISM
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Tropical storm probability
page.title: Tropical storm probability
page.description:
Decile estimates of tropical storm risk.

Role in models

In regions susceptible to tropical storms and with steep slopes, tropical storm probability is included with annual precipitation as an influence on runoff, since these extreme storm events can cause larger event-based episodes of erosion. Runoff estimates are then used along with soil erodiblity and vegetative maturity to estimate overall erosion in probabilistic erosion source models.

Representation

Data are in deciles of tropical storm risk.

Source

CIESIN Hazards Data.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: CIESIN Hazards data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual runoff
page.title: Annual runoff
page.description:
Runoff as used to estimate soil erosion, along with soil and vegetation characteristics.

Role in models

Runoff estimates can be used to train Bayesian networks when using probabilistic models of erosion.

Representation

Data are physical units of millimeters of runoff per year.

Source

UNH GRDC Composite Runoff Data.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: UNH GRDC Composite Runoff Data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types have different abilities to reduce soil erosion, based on attributes including vegetation height, life form, rooting depth and density.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation in reducing soil erosion.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from land cover classes.

Source

Southwest Regional GAP Analysis (SWReGAP) land cover data.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analayis land cover Data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Mountain pine beetle damage class
page.title: Mountain pine beetle damage class
page.description:
Mountain pine beetle (_Dendroctonus ponderosae_), a native beetle in western North America, can cause changes to forest structure in beetle-infested forests.

Role in models

Mountain pine beetle-induced death in western forests causes changes to forest structure and hydrologic processes.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from aerial surveys of mountain pine beetle damage.

Source

Derived from USDA-Forest Service aerial survey data.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: USDA Forest Service, Forest Health Protection and its partners.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Percent tree canopy cover
page.title: Percent tree canopy cover
page.description:
Percent tree canopy cover.

Role in models

Tree canopy cover is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation in reducing soil erosion. All else being equal, greater protection from soil erosion is expected under higher tree canopy cover.

Representation

Data show the percentage of the land surface under tree canopy cover.

Source

National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD, U.S.); University of Maryland - Global Land Cover Facility (global).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: National Land Cover Dataset., University of Maryland Global Land Cover Facility.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Percent tree canopy cover
page.title: Percent tree canopy cover
page.description:

Representation

Data show the percentage of the land surface under tree canopy cover.

Source

National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD, U.S.); University of Maryland - Global Land Cover Facility (global).

page.credits:

page.title: Percent tree canopy cover

Role in models

Data sources: National Land Cover Dataset., University of Maryland Global Land Cover Facility.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Successional stage
page.title: Successional stage
page.description:
Forest succession stage influences attributes such as vegetation height, tree canopy cover, root densities, and litter and woody debris cover, all of which can potentially reduce soil erosion.

Role in models

Successional stage is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation in reducing soil erosion. All else being equal, later successional forests are expected to provide greater protection from soil erosion.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

BLM Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project (WA/OR); LANDFIRE (U.S.).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project, LANDFIRE.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

BLM Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project (WA/OR); LANDFIRE (U.S.).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:

Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual sediment source
page.title: Annual sediment source
page.description:
Annual soil erosion from the landscape.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of vegetation, soils, and precipitation on erosion. These data are passed to the sediment flow model, which calculates actual sediment delivered to beneficiaries, given erosion levels, the activity of sinks, and the location of beneficiaries of sedimentation or avoided sedimentation.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tons of sediment eroded per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of sediment eroded. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area. U.S. EPA EMAP-West Metric Browser data (U.S.) and Yang, D., et al. 2003. Global potential soil erosion with reference to land use and climate changes. Hydrological Processes 17: 2913-2928 (global) were used for Bayesian network training.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: U.S. EPA EMAP-West Metric Browser, Yang et al. (2003).
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual sediment source
page.title: Annual sediment source
page.description:
Annual soil erosion from the landscape.

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of vegetation, soils, and precipitation on erosion. page.name: Reservoir presence
page.title: Reservoir presence
page.description:
Reservoirs stop the downstream movement of sediment by trapping it in the reservoir and releasing low-sediment water downstream.

Role in models

Deposition of nearly all suspended sediment is expected to occur in reservoirs. Deposition in reservoirs is summed with deposition in floodplains to give a total flood sink value.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of reservoirs.

Source

National Atlas of the United States, Major Dams of the United States (U.S.); FAO AQUASTAT (Africa); Global Database of Dams (global).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: Major dams of the United States, FAO AQUASTAT, Global Database of Dams.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Stream gradient
page.title: Stream gradient
page.description:
Stream gradient helps dictate the speed of floodwater flows, causing sediment to either be deposited or remain suspended as it flows downstream.

Role in models

Stream gradient enters into a probabilistic model to estimate sediment sink values. Deposition values are assumed to be higher along low-gradient streams, where slower-flowing water promotes deposition.

Representation

Data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Derived from local hydrography data and SRTM slope data.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Floodplain tree canopy cover
page.title: Floodplain tree canopy cover
page.description:
Well-vegetatated floodplains can better trap sediment by slowing the flow of floodwater and providing microtopography where sediment can be deposited.

Role in models

Floodplain tree canopy cover enters into a probabilistic model to estimate sediment sink values. Deposition values are assumed to be higher in more forested floodplains, where vegetation can better trap sediment.

Representation

Data show the percentage of the floodplain under tree canopy cover.

Source

National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD, U.S.); University of Maryland - Global Land Cover Facility (global).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: National Land Cover Dataset, University of Maryland Global Land Cover Facility.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Floodplain width
page.title: Floodplain width
page.description:
Wider floodplains can promote sediment deposition by slowing the flow of sediment-carrying floodwater.

Role in models

Floodplain width is used as input data for a probabilistic model to estimate sediment sink values. Deposition values are assumed to be higher in wide floodplains, where floodwater can spread out and move more slowly, leading to deposition.

Representation

Data are in physical units of meters of floodplain width.

Source

Derived from FEMA Q3 Flood Data (U.S.); Dartmouth Flood Observatory (global).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: FEMA Q3 Flood Data, Dartmouth Flood Observatory.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual sediment sink
page.title: Annual sediment sink
page.description:
The deposition of waterborne sediment in floodplains.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of floodplain characteristics on sediment deposition. These data are passed to the sediment flow model, which calculates actual sediment delivered to beneficiaries, given erosion levels, the activity of sinks, and the location of beneficiaries of sedimentation or avoided sedimentation.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tons of sediment deposited per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of sediment deposited. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Floodplain sediment sink
page.title: Floodplain sediment sink
page.description:
The total deposition of waterborne sediment in floodplains and reservoirs.

Role in models

This is the total summed sediment deposition in floodplains and reservoirs. These data are passed to the flood flow model, which calculates actual sediment flows given the locations of sediment sources, sinks, and users.

Representation

Data are in physical units of tons of sediment deposited per year.

Source

Calculated as the sum of outputs from a probabilistic model of floodplain sediment deposition plus deposition in reservoirs.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Hydroelectric use level
page.title: Hydroelectric use level
page.description:
The storage capacity of floodwater by dams, used as a proxy for power generation capacity.

Role in models

The potential hydroelectric generating capacity of a dam is used to measure the impact of sedimentation on power generating capacity. These data are use values for hydroelectric dams as beneficiaries of sediment regulation. Their use and location is passed to flow models which map actual sediment delivery to reservoirs.

Representation

Data are in physical units of cubic meters of storage capacity by reservoir.

Source

National Atlas of the United States, Major Dams of the United States.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Major dams of the United States,
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Hydroelectric use presence
page.title: Hydroelectric use presence
page.description:
When dam storage capacities are unavailable, reservoir location data are used to map impacts of sedimentation on hydroelectric generation.

Role in models

The location of reservoirs for hydroelectric dams, where generation capacity or storage data are unavailable. These data are use values for hydroelectric dams as beneficiaries of sediment regulation. Their use and location is passed to flow models which map actual sediment delivery to reservoirs.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of reservoirs.

Source

FAO AQUASTAT (Africa); Global Database of Dams (global).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: FAO AQUASTAT, Global Database of Dams.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Elevation
page.title: Elevation
page.description:
Elevation above sea level.

Role in models

A digital elevation model is used along with hydrography data to route sediment-carrying water across the land surface. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which water then follows through the stream network.

Representation

Data are in physical units of meters above sea level.

Source

Global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Rivers
page.title: Rivers
page.description:
River and stream locations.

Role in models

Hydrography data are used to route sediment-carrying surface water. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which water then follows through the stream network.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of rivers and streams.

Source

Digital Chart of the World (Dominican Republic); Foiben-Taosarintanin'i Madagasikara (FTM, Madagascar); Colorado Department of Transportation (Colorado, U.S.); Washington Department of Natural Resources (Washington State, U.S.).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: Foiben-Taosarintanin'i Madagasikara, Washington State DNR, Colorado DOT.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Levees
page.title: Levees
page.description:
Levees restrict a river's flow to its channel, limiting the ability of floodwater to spread across the floodplain and deposit sediment.

Role in models

Levee location data are used in the flow model to limit the spread of floodwater across the floodplain when levees are present, eliminating the possibility of sediment deposition beyond levees.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of levees.

Source

County GIS offices (where available).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Possible sediment flow
page.title: Possible sediment flow
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* show the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows downstream sediment movement when not accounting for sediment sinks (i.e., areas of deposition).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Possible sediment source
page.title: Possible sediment source
page.description:
*Possible source maps*, generated through flow analysis, show which specific sources actually generate carriers that reach users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account use values and the carrier flow paths. Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity can actually reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the sources that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows areas which, based on sediment flows but when not accounting for sinks (i.e., depositional areas), provide sediment which reaches downstream users who either benefit from or are damaged by sediment delivery.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Possible reduced sediment deposition beneficiaries
page.title: Possible reduced sediment deposition beneficiaries
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map shows beneficiaries who receive beneficial or detrimental sedimentation when accounting for flow paths but not sinks.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual sediment flow
page.title: Actual sediment flow
page.description:
*Actual flow maps* show the flow paths that deliver actual services to beneficiaries. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this case, the density of actual flows shows the downstream movement of sediment when accounting for sediment sinks (i.e., areas of deposition).
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual sediment source
page.title: Actual sediment source
page.description:
*Actual source maps* show sources that actually provide a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics.
For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier that was neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows areas which, based on sediment flows and accounting for sinks (i.e., depositional areas), provide sediment to downstream users who either benefit from or are damaged by sediment delivery.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual deposition
page.title: Utilized sediment deposition
page.description:
*Actual sink maps* shows the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns.
For provisioning services, such sinks reduce benefits to users compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows depositional areas that undergo sedimentation, receiving upstream sediment and actively performing a sediment trapping function.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual reduced sediment deposition beneficiaries
page.title: Actual reduced sediment deposition beneficiaries
page.description:
*Actual use maps* show the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users.
This map shows beneficiaries who receive beneficial or detrimental sedimentation when accounting for flow paths and sinks.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Unutilized sediment source
page.title: Unutilized sediment source
page.description:
*Inaccessible source maps* show source areas whose values are irrelevant to ecosystem service delivery, because of a lack of flow connections between sources and users.
For provisioning services, this is the portion of the value that must be subtracted from the total source map to define a maximum potential benefit for the users. For preventive services, it shows those areas that have no potential of producing damage because the flow dynamics prevent the carrier from impacting any significant user.
This map shows areas which, based on sediment flows, do not provide sediment to downstream users who either benefit from or are damaged by sediment delivery.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Absorbed sediment flow
page.title: Absorbed sediment flow
page.description:
*Blocked flow maps* show flow paths that could have delivered an ecosystem service to humans based on the flow routes and source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss of possible beneficial service flow to users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows the flow of sediment that does not reach downstream beneficiaries. These beneficiaries either benefit from avoided detrimental sedimentation or lose the delivery of beneficial sediment.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Negated sediment source
page.title: Negated sediment source
page.description:
*Blocked source maps* show sources that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of users and flow dynamics, but were blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it could reach the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows areas which, based on the deposition occurring in sinks areas, do not provide sediment to downstream users who either benefit from or are damaged by sediment delivery.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Blocked harmful sediment
page.title: Blocked harmful sediment
page.description:
*Blocked use maps* show users that would have received a service carrier based on source and flow dynamics, but did not because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that were prevented by sinks from reaching users; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users from sinks that blocked damaging flows. For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and sink features.
This map shows beneficiaries who receive less detrimental sediment as a result of sinks where sediment deposition occurs.
page.see-also: Sediment regulation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.
